semantic_identifier: 4288737 - Highridge Data Services - buy - Discussion with Tatum Green

hierarchy.meeting_title: 4288737 - Highridge Data Services - buy - Discussion with Tatum Green

sections.text: Irene Shen: Hi Tatum—good to see you again. Since this is our third call, I’d love to use today to confirm the last couple open items and, if everything checks out, align on next steps to get Highridge live with Customer_Analyzer. Sound good?

Tatum Green: Yeah, that works. We’re interested—this is mostly about making sure it’ll be clean with how we segment customers, and then understanding what we’re actually buying and how fast we’ll see value.

Irene Shen: Perfect. Let’s anchor on two things: (1) Fit estimation—because that’s the engine that tells you who your best customers really are and why, and (2) the driver breakdown and segment comparisons—because that’s what turns the score into something your product and marketing teams can act on for planning. Then we’ll address the segmentation ambiguity concern head-on.

Tatum Green: Great. The fit score is compelling, but I want to avoid a situation where it gives us “meh” recommendations because our segments overlap. We have healthcare and fintech customers, but also “data ops” personas across both, and it gets messy.

Irene Shen: Totally common—and solvable. Customer_Analyzer doesn’t force you into one rigid segmentation lens. What we recommend is setting up a primary segmentation framework for decision-making, then allowing secondary tags for overlap. For example: primary segment = industry + company size, and secondary = persona or use case like “data ops / analytics modernization.” The fit estimation can then compare clean segment buckets, while still letting you slice by those cross-cutting tags.
Tatum Green: Okay, but how does the product actually handle that? Like, do we have to manually define all of it?

Irene Shen: You can start lightweight. You define a small set of fit drivers—firmographics like industry and size, plus a couple of signals you already have, like problem severity from onboarding survey responses, adoption from product usage events, and support burden from ticket volume. Then Customer_Analyzer computes a fit score 0–100 at the account level and aggregates it at the segment level. Where it gets really actionable is the driver breakdown: it tells you, “This segment scores 82 because time-to-value is fast and adoption is high; this other segment scores 54 because support burden is high and willingness-to-pay signals are weak.”
Tatum Green: And those signals come from our systems—CRM, tickets, product analytics?

Irene Shen: Exactly. On your side, you’ve already mentioned Salesforce fields, Intercom/Zendesk tickets, and product events in Segment. Those are the big three. We ingest those signals and normalize them so you don’t have to build a custom pipeline. Then for product planning—your use case—we can connect fit outcomes to retention and expansion trends. So it’s not just “this looks like a good customer,” it’s “this segment historically renews and expands, and here are the drivers that correlate.”
Tatum Green: That’s the part our product team wants. They’re constantly debating roadmap bets based on the loudest customers.

Irene Shen: Right—and the tool helps you shift from “loudest” to “highest-fit with unmet needs.” The segment comparisons view is what teams tend to use in roadmap discussions. For example, you can compare SMB healthcare vs mid-market healthcare, or fintech mid-market vs fintech enterprise, and see which segments show higher fit and where the friction is coming from—time-to-value, adoption curve, support load, churn risk signals. Then you can decide: do we invest to improve fit for a segment we want, or do we stop chasing a segment that’s structurally misaligned?

Tatum Green: I like that framing. But let’s go back to the ambiguity issue. We’ve had tools in the past that basically produced conflicting outputs because one account could fall into multiple categories.

Irene Shen: Yep. The way we prevent “confusing recommendations” is by being explicit about what “segment” means in a given analysis. Two best practices we’ll implement with you:
1) Mutually exclusive segment definitions for the main comparisons. We’ll agree on a hierarchy—say, industry first, then size band—so every account lands in exactly one “primary segment.”
2) Overlap handled as attributes, not competing segments. Persona, use case, tech stack—those become filters or tags that you can apply after you’ve established the clean baseline.
We also show you the composition of each segment—so if a segment is accidentally heterogeneous, it’s visible immediately.
Tatum Green: So we won’t end up with a healthcare segment that’s secretly half fintech because of how fields were mapped.

Irene Shen: Exactly. And during onboarding we do a “segment sanity check” where we look at your top segments by ARR and by logo count and confirm the definitions match how Highridge talks about the market. If something overlaps, we adjust the hierarchy. That’s usually a 30–45 minute working session.
Tatum Green: That helps. Now, value timeline—what’s realistic? We don’t want a three-month science project.

Irene Shen: Completely aligned. Typical timeline: week one, connect data sources and define the initial fit drivers. Week two, you get your first fit scores and segment comparisons, plus a short readout. The goal by end of week two is: “Here are the top two high-fit segments, here are the bottom two, and here are the driver-level reasons.” Then week three and four is refinement—adding one or two more drivers if needed and calibrating based on feedback.
Tatum Green: And do we have to be perfect with drivers up front?

Irene Shen: No—start with 6–8 drivers max. You’ll get value even with a simple model: industry, size, time-to-value proxy, early adoption, support burden, and churn risk signals. Then you refine once the team sees what’s missing. The key is that the driver breakdown makes it transparent—so you’re not trusting a black box.
Tatum Green: Okay. Commercially, we’re close. I just need confidence that this won’t turn into endless debates about “the model.”

Irene Shen: That’s fair. The way we avoid that is we tie the fit estimation back to outcomes you already trust—retention, expansion, conversion. We’ll set a baseline: “When fit is above X, what happens to renewal?” If the relationship is weak, we adjust the drivers. If it’s strong, it becomes a shared language across product, marketing, and sales—without philosophical debates.
Tatum Green: That’s a good point. If we can show, say, high-fit segments retain better, it’s easier to align.

Irene Shen: Exactly. So here’s what I’m proposing to get this over the line: we start with the Customer_Analyzer package scoped for your product planning use case—fit estimation plus segment comparisons and driver breakdown. During onboarding, we’ll include that segment definition working session specifically to address the ambiguity risk. If you’re good with that, we can finalize today and book kickoff for next week.
Tatum Green: Before we finalize—what does “finalize today” mean? Contract signature and then kickoff?

Irene Shen: Yes. We’d send the order form right after this call. Once signed, we schedule kickoff, connect data sources, and set your initial segment framework and fit drivers. I can also include a short success plan doc so you can forward it internally: milestones by week and what “value delivered” looks like.
Tatum Green: That would help. One more question: if we realize our segment hierarchy is wrong after a month, are we stuck?

Irene Shen: Not stuck. You can change segment definitions any time. What we’ll do is version it: keep “v1 segments” for continuity, then test “v2 segments” and compare results. That way you don’t lose historical context, but you also aren’t locked into early assumptions.
Tatum Green: Good. I think we’re ready. I just need to confirm procurement won’t slow us down—our VP is supportive, and I’m the one driving it.
Irene Shen: Great—what’s the cleanest path? If I send the order form today, can you get signature this week?
Tatum Green: Yes. If you send it in the next hour, I can route it today. Assuming terms are standard, we should be able to sign by Thursday.

Irene Shen: Perfect. I’ll send it right after we hang up. Last check: are we aligned that the main success criteria for Highridge is: identify the top two high-fit segments for focus, identify one “high-fit but unmet needs” segment to inform roadmap bets, and socialize the driver-based rationale with product and marketing?
Tatum Green: Yes, that’s exactly it. And if we can reduce the internal arguing about which customers to prioritize, that’s a win.
Irene Shen: Love it. I’ll include those as the success criteria in the kickoff plan. Any red flags I should anticipate from legal or security?
Tatum Green: Security will ask about data handling, but we’ve already reviewed your overview. Just include the standard security docs in the email and we’ll attach them to the ticket.

Irene Shen: Will do. So next steps: I send order form + security packet + one-page success plan today; you route for signature; we book kickoff for early next week; and in week two you’ll have the first fit score outputs and segment comparisons.
Tatum Green: Sounds good. Send it over and I’ll get it moving.
Irene Shen: Great. Thanks, Tatum—excited to get Customer_Analyzer live at Highridge. I’ll follow up in a few minutes with everything.
Tatum Green: Thanks, Irene. Talk soon.
